message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Adaptive Fixed-Time Control of Nonlinear MASs With Actuator Faults
Paper Abstract: The adaptive fixed-time consensus problem for a class of nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs) with actuator faults is considered in this paper. To approximate the unknown nonlinear functions in MASs, radial basis function neural networks are used. In addition, the first order sliding mode differentiator is utilized to solve the "explosion of complexity" problem, and a filter error compensation method is proposed to ensure the convergence of filter error in fixed time. With the help of the Nussbaum function, the actuator failure compensation mechanism is constructed. By designing the adaptive fixed-time controller, all signals in MASs are bounded, and the consensus errors between the leader and all followers converge to a small area of origin. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed control method is verified by simulation examples.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "Artificial neural network". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

An artificial neural network (ANN) is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks.(no content)A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.

## Structure and Function

These neurons are connected by edges, which model the synapses in the brain. Each artificial neuron receives signals from connected neurons, then processes them and sends a signal to other connected neurons.(no content)The "signal" is a real number, and the output of each neuron is computed by some non-linear function of the totality of its inputs, called the activation function.(no content)Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).

## Applications and Learning

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence. They can learn from experience, and can derive conclusions from a complex and seemingly unrelated set of information.

## Historical Development

In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research. Since then, the field has evolved significantly with developments like backpropagation algorithms, deep learning, and transformer models.

## Adaptive Control

Based on the search results, here's information about adaptive control:

### Definition

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### Key Differences from Other Control Methods

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

### Categories

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

### Modern Applications

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.(no content)A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

## Multi-Agent System Search Results

I found comprehensive information about multi-agent systems. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition
A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

### Key Capabilities
Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Components and Characteristics
Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents have several important characteristics: Autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous) and Decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling). Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

### Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Related Research
The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Chen Guanrong - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Guanrong"}]

## Overview of Nonlinear Control Theory

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

### Key Differences from Linear Control

Linear control theory applies to systems made of devices which obey the superposition principle. They are governed by linear differential equations. A major subclass is systems which in addition have parameters which do not change with time, called linear time invariant (LTI) systems. In contrast, nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems thatdo not obey the superposition principle.

### Analysis Techniques

Nonlinear systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations. The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems. These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

### Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system. A building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off", it does not have the fine control in response to temperature differences that a proportional (linear) device would have.

### Advantages of Nonlinear Controllers

Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Chen Guanrong - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Guanrong"}]

## Overview of Nonlinear Control Theory

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

### Key Differences from Linear Control

Linear control theory applies to systems made of devices which obey the superposition principle. They are governed by linear differential equations. A major subclass is systems which in addition have parameters which do not change with time, called linear time invariant (LTI) systems. In contrast, nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems thatdo not obey the superposition principle.

### Analysis Techniques

Nonlinear systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations. The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems. These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

### Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system. A building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off", it does not have the fine control in response to temperature differences that a proportional (linear) device would have.

### Advantages of Nonlinear Controllers

Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.

Links: [{"title":"Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Radial basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Radial basis function kernel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_kernel"},{"title":"Radial basis function interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_interpolation"},{"title":"Talk:Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"File:4 Normalized radial basis functions.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:4_Normalized_radial_basis_functions.svg"},{"title":"Hierarchical RBF - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_RBF"},{"title":"Hyper basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Kansa method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansa_method"},{"title":"Thin plate spline - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thin_plate_spline"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Radial Basis Functions:

## Definition

A radial basis function (RBF) is a real-valued function whose value depends only on the distance between the input and some fixed point. More specifically, functions that depend only on the distance from a center vector are radially symmetric about that vector, hence the name radial basis function.

## Applications

RBFs have diverse applications across multiple fields:

**Machine Learning & Neural Networks:**
RBFs were applied to machine learning in work by David Broomhead and David Lowe in 1988, which stemmed from Michael J. D. Powell's seminal research from 1977. A radial basis function network is an artificial neural network that uses radial basis functions as activation functions, with uses including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control. Additionally, RBFs are also used as a kernel in support vector classification.

**Scientific Computing:**
Radial basis functions are used to approximate functions and so can be used to discretize and numerically solve Partial Differential Equations (PDEs), first done in 1990 by E. J. Kansa who developed the first RBF based numerical method.

**Computer Graphics:**
Hierarchical RBF interpolation has applications in treatment of results from a 3D scanner, terrain reconstruction, and the construction of shape models in 3D computer graphics (such as the Stanford bunny, a popular 3D model).

## Network Structure

Radial basis function (RBF) networks typically have three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with a non-linear RBF activation function and a linear output layer.

Web search results for query: "Sliding mode control"

Links: [{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Terminal sliding mode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_sliding_mode"},{"title":"Integral sliding mode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral_sliding_mode"},{"title":"Talk:Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Predictive control of switching power converters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictive_control_of_switching_power_converters"},{"title":"Runner3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runner3"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about sliding mode control:

## Definition

Sliding mode control (SMC) is a nonlinear control method that alters the dynamics of a nonlinear system by applying a discontinuous control signal that forces the system to "slide" along a cross-section of the system's normal behavior.

## How It Works

Sliding mode control uses practically infinite gain to force the trajectories of a dynamic system to slide along the restricted sliding mode subspace.(no content)The control law can switch from one continuous structure to another based on the current position in the state space, making sliding mode control a variable structure control method.

## Key Advantages

The main strength of sliding mode control is its robustness.(no content)Because the control can be as simple as a switching between two states (e.g., "on"/"off" or "forward"/"reverse"), it need not be precise and will not be sensitive to parameter variations that enter into the control channel. Additionally, because the control law is not a continuous function, the sliding mode can be reached in finite time (i.e., better than asymptotic behavior).

## Challenges

Real implementations of sliding mode control approximate theoretical behavior with a high-frequency and generally non-deterministic switching control signal that causes the system to "chatter" in a tight neighborhood of the sliding surface.(no content)Because actuators have delays and other imperfections, the hard sliding-mode-control action can lead to chatter, energy loss, plant damage, and excitation of unmodeled dynamics.

## Applications

Sliding mode control has many applications in robotics, and in particular, this control algorithm has been used for tracking control of unmanned surface vessels in simulated rough seas with high degree of success.

Web search results for query: "Consensus distributed systems"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Paxos (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Raft (algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raft_(algorithm)"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Distributed algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_algorithm"},{"title":"Distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control_system"},{"title":"Consistency model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistency_model"},{"title":"Distributed operating system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_operating_system"},{"title":"Quorum (distributed computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quorum_(distributed_computing)"},{"title":"Distributed ledger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_ledger"}]

Here's an overview of consensus in distributed systems based on the search results:

## Definition and Purpose

A fundamental problem in distributed computing is achieving overall system reliability in the presence of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus—agreeing on some data value that is needed during computation.

## Key Challenges

In a fully asynchronous message-passing distributed system in which at least one process may have a crash failure, it has been proven in the famous 1985 FLP impossibility result that a deterministic algorithm for achieving consensus is impossible. However, this does not state that consensus can never be reached; merely that under the model's assumptions, no algorithm can always reach consensus in bounded time.

## Practical Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants like Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems. These algorithms are typically synchronous, dependent on an elected leader to make progress, and tolerate only crashes and not Byzantine failures.(no content)Raft is a consensus algorithm designed as an alternative to the Paxos family of algorithms. It was meant to be more understandable than Paxos by means of separation of logic, but it is also formally proven safe and offers some additional features.

## Real-World Applications

Consensus protocols are the basis for the state machine replication approach to distributed computing, a technique for converting an algorithm into a fault-tolerant, distributed implementation. These algorithms are used in systems like Google's Chubby, Amazon DynamoDB, and many other distributed databases and cloud services.

Consensus protocols are the basis for the state machine replication approach to distributed computing, a technique for converting an algorithm into a fault-tolerant, distributed implementation. These algorithms are used in systems like Google's Chubby, Amazon DynamoDB, and many other distributed databases and cloud services.

Here's an overview of consensus in distributed systems based on the search results:

## Definition and Purpose

A fundamental problem in distributed computing is achieving overall system reliability in the presence of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus—agreeing on some data value that is needed during computation.

## Key Challenges

In a fully asynchronous message-passing distributed system in which at least one process may have a crash failure, it has been proven in the famous 1985 FLP impossibility result that a deterministic algorithm for achieving consensus is impossible. However, this does not state that consensus can never be reached; merely that under the model's assumptions, no algorithm can always reach consensus in bounded time.

## Practical Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants like Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems. These algorithms are typically synchronous, dependent on an elected leader to make progress, and tolerate only crashes and not Byzantine failures.(no content)Raft is a consensus algorithm designed as an alternative to the Paxos family of algorithms. It was meant to be more understandable than Paxos by means of separation of logic, but it is also formally proven safe and offers some additional features.

## Real-World Applications

Consensus protocols are the basis for the state machine replication approach to distributed computing, a technique for converting an algorithm into a fault-tolerant, distributed implementation. These algorithms are used in systems like Google's Chubby, Amazon DynamoDB, and many other distributed databases and cloud services.
